author: By Neil Irwin
title: In the Biden Bill, the Billionaires Beat the Working Rich
description: One by one, tax proposals that would have slowed dynastic wealth have been tossed from the agreement.
content: In the end, it was the millionaires versus the billionaires. The millionaires lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: J.D. Vance and Mar-a-Loco
description: His Trump-flattering campaign for the Senate is an elegy for decency.
content: I seriously doubt that J.D. Vance has scraped the bottom of his barrel — it appears to be a roomy barrel, and he seems to be poised to sink lower and lower — but a tweet of his late last week will surely endure as one of the boldest markers of his descent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deyan Sudjic
title: How the Memphis Design Movement Made a Comeback
description: Why the 1980s design phenomenon, named for a Bob Dylan song and an ancient Egyptian city, still appeals to every generation.
content: To call an armchair or a bookcase “revolutionary” might seem like a stretch, but for the design world, the original show of the Memphis design movement was as genuinely shocking as the first Sex Pistols performance. But unlike his revolutionary punk predecessors, Ettore Sottsass, this design moment’s founder, certainly knew the rules he was breaking when the Memphis group debuted in Milan 40 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: In Fight Over ‘Beloved,’ a Reminder of Literature’s Power
description: Toni Morrison’s novel has roiled the Virginia governor’s race and provided a reason to reflect on the importance of reading things that challenge you.
content: Every day I’m alive is a day I’m thankful that my parents were too busy to supervise my reading as a child. Or too bored by the idea of it. As long as I was relatively clean and not punching my younger brother’s lights out, I pretty much had the run of the house and a one-mile radius surrounding it. Included in that roaming zone was Green Apple Books, a cherished San Francisco institution packed to the beams with new books, old books, blue books and paperbacks from the 1970s that reeked so powerfully of menthol cigarettes and camphor that I often emerged with that same scent wafting from my stretchy purple turtleneck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: U.S. Recovery Hurt by Virus Surge and Supply Chain Troubles
description: New data shows how bottlenecks and the Delta variant slowed economic growth in the third quarter. Relief may be slow.
content: Economic growth slowed sharply over the summer, the government reported Thursday, reflecting the resurgent pandemic’s impact in keeping consumers at home and the supply-chain bottlenecks that led to empty shelves and higher prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘Caroline, or Change’ Makes History’s Heartbreak Sing
description: An electrifying revival of the 2003 musical, featuring a titanic performance by Sharon D Clarke, follows the money to the source of American inequality.
content: Difficult, even painful stories are no impediment to great musicals. Maybe the opposite is true. Pogroms, suicides and revolutions have all been turned into transcendent shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Nayeri and Norimitsu Onishi
title: Looted Treasures Begin a Long Journey Home From France
description: The return to Benin of 26 ransacked objects will be the first large-scale act of restitution to Africa by a former European colonial power.
content: PARIS — More than a century after French colonial troops ransacked a West African royal palace and took its treasures, President Emmanuel Macron of France on Wednesday began the formal transfer of 26 of those artifacts to Benin in the first large-scale act of restitution to Africa by a former European colonial power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Attica’ Review: Reflections on a Riot
description: The Showtime documentary, directed by Stanley Nelson, looks back on the 1971 prison uprising with the benefit of 50 years’ hindsight.
content: “Attica,” a documentary from Stanley Nelson, is hardly the first screen attempt to deal with the Attica prison riot of 1971, when inmates took control of part of the penitentiary and, holding hostages, demanded better living conditions before authorities violently subdued them on the fifth day. The presence of TV cameras at the time helped keep the events in the national news, and a blistering 1974 documentary by Cinda Firestone looked back on the uprising almost contemporaneously, with sympathy for the reformist perspective and outrage at the bloodshed perpetrated by officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Taking the Loop Less Traveled on the Oregon Coast
description: The Three Capes area offers a quieter version of the classic road trip, with rugged scenery and hidden beaches off the main highway.
content: The tiny hamlet of Netarts, Ore., protected by a long spit of sand from the Pacific Ocean’s churn, is so small you might miss it if you didn’t know it was there. But on a Saturday morning in October, Netarts Bay was alive with small motorboats and kayaks, whose occupants were searching for the delectable crabs and scallops that thrive in its briny waters, as the oystermen waited for low tide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘How They Got Over’ Review: How Gospel Begat Rock
description: In the director Robert Clem’s documentary about gospel quartets and their undeniable influence on rock ’n’ roll, Sister Rosetta Tharpe has competition.
content: Sister Rosetta Tharpe nearly steals the show in “How They Got Over,” the director Robert Clem’s documentary about the gospel quartets of the 1920s, ’30s and ’40s and their undeniable influence on rock ’n’ roll. But she has competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Childhood vaccinations have lagged across the world because of the pandemic.
description: Millions of young children did not get immunized against polio, measles and other diseases.
content: The pandemic dealt a serious setback to global efforts to immunize children against diseases like measles and polio, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Thursday, reducing worldwide coverage for some vaccines to levels not seen since more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: TriBeCa Gallery Guide: New York’s Most Vibrant Art Scene
description: The large-scale arrival of new and veteran dealers has given the neighborhood its first unifying theme in 60 years. Here are three walks with our critics, a springboard to explore.
content: Galleries have been moving to TriBeCa for a good five years, but the migration has finally hit critical mass. As everyone from tiny new project spaces to the blue-chip titan David Zwirner floods in, this cast-iron and cobblestone neighborhood in Manhattan — south of Canal, north of Vesey and west of Broadway — is no longer just one option of many. For any New York-area gallery that needs to move or is opening another branch, TriBeCa is now the most exciting place to show contemporary art — the destination that has to be considered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Chess of the Wind’ Review: A Remnant of an Iran That Used to Be
description: Mohammad Reza Aslani’s 1976 film about family mendacity existed for mere days before it was banned and then lost in the ensuing tumult. Now it’s back.
content: This 1976 movie arrives in New York with an ideal restoration narrative. “Chess of the Wind” was made in Iran and screened only briefly before being banned in the tense period leading up to the Islamic revolution. Presumed lost, the film’s negative turned up in a junk shop years later. Distinguished cinephile organizations then kicked in to make it internationally accessible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: Two Tenors. Many, Many High Notes.
description: Lawrence Brownlee and Michael Spyres came together for a sky-scraping Rossini concert at the 92nd Street Y.
content: Fans of N.F.L. RedZone — the TV channel that whips around the country each Sunday during football season to show you, it promises, “every touchdown from every game” — will have felt a familiar sensation on Wednesday at the 92nd Street Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Clearview AI finally takes part in a federal accuracy test.
description: Thousands of local and state police departments are customers for Clearview’s facial recognition tool, the company says.
content: Clearview AI scraped more than 10 billion photos from the public internet to build a facial-recognition tool that it marketed to law enforcement agencies for identifying unknown people. Critics have said the company’s product is illegal, unethical and untested. Now, more than two years after law enforcement officers first started using the company’s app, Clearview’s algorithm — what allows it to match faces to photos — has been put to a third-party test for the first time. It performed surprisingly well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: To Save a Swirling Season, Atlanta Turned to Soft Serve
description: Atlanta has been praised for its shrewd deadline trades. Braves players credit their resurgence to a midseason pickup that produces day after day.
content: ATLANTA — The Atlanta Braves are making their first World Series appearance since 1999 because of star players at several positions, an underrated pitching staff and shrewd midsummer moves by the front office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Andrew Cuomo Is Charged in Sexual Misconduct Complaint
description: Mr. Cuomo, the former governor of New York, resigned in August after a state attorney general report concluded that he had sexually harassed multiple women.
content: Former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was charged on Thursday with groping a female aide’s breast inside the Executive Mansion “for the purposes of degrading and gratifying his sexual desires,” according to a criminal complaint filed in Albany City Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Lawyer Who Won $9.5 Billion Judgment Against Chevron Reports to Prison
description: Steven Donziger, an environmental activist who won what is considered the largest ever lawsuit against an oil company, was found guilty of contempt of court in July.
content: Steven Donziger, the environmental and human rights lawyer who won a $9.5 billion settlement against Chevron over oil dumped in Indigenous lands in the Amazon rainforest, surrendered himself to the federal authorities on Wednesday to begin a six-month prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rania Abouzeid
title: How Corruption Ruined Lebanon
description: The deadly port blast, the triple-digit inflation, the energy shortages — Lebanon’s many crises have a shared root: misrule by a self-dealing elite.
content: The head of Lebanon’s Central Inspection Board, Judge Georges Attieh, stood in his mother’s fourth-floor apartment, his childhood home in Beirut, and pushed open a new, white window shutter. A sharp winter chill stole into the room, bare except for a neat stack of gray cinder blocks. A few steps away, a damaged piano covered in a floral sheet was surrounded by a jumble of objects: broken dining chairs, cardboard boxes, a clothes steamer, rolled-up rugs. Attieh looked out at the flat blue sea visible between the few buildings that separated his mother’s apartment from the Port of Beirut. “I haven’t been here in six months, even though I drive by here every day,” he said. “I can’t. I’m unable to come here. It isn’t easy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: High-Protein Veggie Recipes for Beginners and Beyond
description: Readers requested recipes for getting their protein, and we have some delicious ideas.
content: I love getting emails from readers with requests and questions, and lately there have been quite a few about … protein! If you’re newly vegetarian, and you’re not sure where to get your protein, the short, tasty answer is: You’ll find it in all kinds of lentils and beans (which we cooked last week!), including food products made from beans, such as tofu, as well as nuts and some seeds. If you’re not vegan, you can also look to eggs, cheeses and yogurts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: France Detains British Boat as a Fight Over Fishing Rights Escalates
description: The British government summoned France’s ambassador for talks over the incident, the latest sign of cross-Channel tension between the two countries.
content: PARIS — French authorities said Thursday that they had detained a British fishing trawler, prompting the government in London to summon France’s ambassador for talks, escalating months of rising tension between the two nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: An immigration overhaul is part of Biden’s $1.85 trillion plan.
description: Included in the plan is a proposal to protect millions of undocumented immigrants who are longtime residents of the country from deportation.
content: President Biden on Thursday proposed devoting $100 billion in his $1.85 trillion domestic policy bill to protect millions of undocumented immigrants, pushing to salvage a broader immigration overhaul that has stalled in Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Students Describe Their Pandemic Experience in Six-Word Memoirs
description: Wake up, get on Zoom, repeat.
content: This post is part of The Learning Network’s weekly Current Events Conversation feature, in which we publish a selection of notable student comments on our daily writing prompts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whitney Bauck
title: Disaster Prep Kits Get a Makeover
description: The climate crisis has spawned an unlikely new area of fashion entrepreneurship.
content: Before last year, Whitney McGuire hadn’t seriously considered stashing an emergency survival kit in her home. But as 2020’s record-breaking fire season descended on the West Coast, the attorney, sustainability strategist and mother, who lives in Brooklyn, found herself considering what she might need to prepare if climate change-related disaster were to strike closer to home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Producers of Alec Baldwin Film Scrutinized After Shooting
description: The team behind “Rust” chose not to get an insurance package often carried by productions, which some in Hollywood said was a sign of cutting corners.
content: LOS ANGELES — Independent film productions that cost more than a few million dollars often carry two forms of insurance in case something goes wrong. Forgoing full coverage, Hollywood veterans say, is less a sign of optimism than corner cutting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Old Power Gear Is Slowing Use of Clean Energy and Electric Cars
description: Some people and businesses seeking to use solar panels, batteries and electric vehicles find they can’t because utility equipment needs an upgrade.
content: Seven months after workers finished installing solar panels atop the Garcia family home near Stanford University, the system is little more than a roof ornament. The problem: The local utility’s equipment is so overloaded that there is no place for the electricity produced by the panels to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: A Social Policy ‘Framework’ Fails to Secure a Biden Victory
description: President Biden went to the Capitol to detail a compromise on social safety net and climate legislation, but he couldn’t break the liberal blockade on another priority, infrastructure.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday unveiled his outline for a $1.85 trillion social safety net and environmental bill, imploring Democrats to put aside their differences and embrace a plan to provide universal prekindergarten, generous support for child care costs and the largest investment ever to combat climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Michelle Wu Makes Her Play for Power in Boston
description: A family crisis diverted Ms. Wu from the stable path her parents planned for her. Now she hopes to become mayor.
content: BOSTON — Michelle Wu was weeks away from her first City Council election when she lost her voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Well Is Your School Handling Covid This Year?
description: Have you dealt with coronavirus exposures since returning to the classroom?
content: What policies does your school have in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus? Are they working?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: How Did Elephants and Walruses Get Their Tusks? It’s a Long Story.
description: A new study reveals how some mammals evolved nature’s most impressive chompers (which are not always used for chomping).
content: Elephants have them. Pigs have them. Narwhals and water deer have them. Tusks are among the most dramatic examples of mammal dentition: ever-growing, projecting teeth used for fighting, foraging, even flirting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Right’s Big Lie About a Sexual Assault in Virginia
description: An attack in a school bathroom had nothing to do with trans issues.
content: This is a story about how the right twisted the sexual assault of a teenager into a culture war fantasy. It’s about how a distorted tale on a conservative website became grist for a nationwide moral panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: A Big Tech critic moves closer to leading the Justice Department’s antitrust division.
description: If confirmed by the full Senate, Jonathan Kanter will join other critics of Silicon Valley in top antitrust positions.
content: A Senate committee on Thursday approved a critic of the tech giants to lead the Justice Department’s antitrust division, sending his nomination to the full Senate for a final vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Wealth Tax
description: What are the pluses and minuses?
content: Most Americans pay an annual wealth tax on their largest asset. It’s called property tax. Each year, they pay an amount equal to a small percentage of the estimated value of their house, and a house is by far the most valuable item that most families own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Leading the News Coverage of ‘This Big, Messy Country of Ours’
description: Jia Lynn Yang, who recently became editor of the National desk, discusses her new job and what she values in journalism and storytelling.
content: Jia Lynn Yang has served as editor of the National desk since February, where she oversees a staff of about 50 reporters and editors. Before joining The Times in 2017, Ms. Yang, 38, was a deputy national security editor at The Washington Post. Before that, she was a business reporter and editor at the Post and Fortune magazine. At the Post, she was part of a team that in 2018 shared the Pulitzer Prize in national reporting with The Times for coverage of Russia’s influence operation in the 2016 election. The following interview with Ms. Yang about her new job has been edited and condensed for clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Barcelona, Drifting, Fires Ronald Koeman as Coach
description: Successive defeats to Real Madrid and Rayo Vallecano convinced Barcelona to fire Koeman, its Dutch manager. Xavi Hernández is a favorite to replace him.
content: Ronald Koeman knew even before he arrived in Barcelona that his journey as the club’s manager had ended. His team had just lost for the second time in four days, beaten by Real Madrid on Sunday and then by modest Rayo Vallecano on Wednesday. It was marooned in ninth place in La Liga. There could be, the club decided, no way back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Third Point, an activist investor, is calling for a breakup of Royal Dutch Shell.
description: The hedge fund wants the company to separate its oil and gas business from initiatives in renewable energy.
content: As Royal Dutch Shell announced its quarterly earnings on Thursday, including a jump in profit that fell short of investors’ expectations, company executives were dealing with an activist hedge fund’s proposal that the oil giant be broken up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Supports Democrats’ Plan to Tax the Richest of the Rich
description: “So that includes Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos and Flo, the Progressive Insurance lady,” Jimmy Fallon joked of the billionaires’ tax.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: New York City’s Most Expensive Neighborhoods
description: While prices were up overall in the third quarter compared to a year ago, they fell in many of the priciest areas.
content: New York City’s real estate market was rich with signs of recovery in the third quarter of 2021. The city’s median sale price was up 16 percent from Q3 2020, to $755,000, and the number of sales increased 145 percent, according to an analysis by Property Shark. (By contrast, the report notes that prices were essentially flat from Q3 2019 to Q3 2020.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: China Evergrande is said to make another bond payment, avoiding default for a second time.
description: Evergrande has warned in securities filings that it could not guarantee it would meet its financial obligations because of challenges it has faced selling assets.
content: China Evergrande, the troubled property giant, made another debt payment ahead of a Friday deadline, averting default for the second time in two weeks, according to one of the company’s bondholders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arlene Hirst
title: Haven’t I Seen You Somewhere?
description: Some of the most innovative and attractive furniture designs are the ones just waiting to be rediscovered.
content: For the last several years, design companies have been exploiting an awakened interest in modernism’s storied past, combing the vast archives of 20th-century furnishings to find forgotten gems that they believe deserve a new audience (not to mention new sales).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Has the Virus Infected Huge Numbers of Younger Children?
description: Federal scientists estimated that more than 40 percent of children aged 5 to 11 had been infected with the coronavirus by June. Outside experts aren’t so sure.
content: A startling statistic emerged as advisers to the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday debated use of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine in children ages 5 to 11. According to one federal scientist, by June an estimated 42 percent of these children had already been infected with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Hochul Acts to Open Up a Government Long Defined by Back-Room Deals
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s broad transparency effort included details of her recusal plans for her husband’s business dealings with the state.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul, under pressure from government watchdog groups, on Thursday released details of a plan to recuse herself from all matters involving Delaware North, the casino and concessions company where her husband is a top executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Authorities Return 248 Looted Antiquities to India
description: Most of the items were seized from storage space operated by Subhash Kapoor, a former Manhattan gallery owner facing illegal trafficking charges in both India and the United States.
content: Investigators in Manhattan returned 248 ancient icons valued at $15 million to India on Thursday and said they hoped to have the art dealer accused of looting most of them back in New York for trial by early next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Reductive Practice of Assigning Book Reviews by Identity
description: Are editors asking reviewers to represent the views of their entire race and gender?
content: Every once in a while, it might be healthy for progressives to stop, look up from the work of making the world a more equitable place and ask, “Wait, is this specific thing we’re doing right now really going to help?” It’s a good rule for life, generally, and it may just save the world from unpleasant outcomes that embarrass us all or, in some cases, produce the exact opposite of what we intend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: After Supreme Court Lifts Stay, Oklahoma Executes Inmate
description: The prisoner, John Marion Grant, convulsed and vomited as he was put to death by lethal injection. The court also cleared the way for another execution next month.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday lifted a stay of execution that a federal appeals court had granted to two Oklahoma death row inmates, clearing the way for the men to be put to death by lethal injection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Here’s what’s in Biden’s $1.85 trillion plan.
description: White House officials refused to say if all holdout Democrats in Congress had expressed support for the framework.
content: President Biden met with lawmakers on Thursday morning to lay out a framework on a $1.85 trillion effort to spend heavily on climate change, child care and a wide range of other economic programs, paid for by an estimated $2 trillion in tax increases on corporations and high earners, though it was not immediately clear if it has the votes to pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Meeting of Francis and Biden Will Highlight Rift With U.S. Bishops
description: The pope and president, who will meet at the Vatican on Friday, are common targets of conservative American bishops seeking to undercut them.
content: VATICAN CITY — When Joseph R. Biden Jr. visits the Vatican on Friday, he will be the third American president Francis has met since becoming pope in 2013. Each has marked a distinct phase not only of his papacy, but also of the political upheaval in the United States and in its Roman Catholic church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Cleveland Roller Derby Team Sues City’s Baseball Team Over ‘Guardians’ Name
description: “To be blunt, Plaintiff was here first,” the Cleveland Guardians roller derby team said in filing a suit claiming trademark infringement.
content: Is Cleveland big enough for two sports teams named the Guardians? A roller derby team that has used the name since 2013 says no.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: N.F.L. Week 8 Predictions: Our Picks Against the Spread
description: Aaron Rodgers’s top two receivers may be out against the 7-0 Cardinals, and the Saints must rely on Alvin Kamara to move past the Buccaneers while the Dolphins stare down the Bills and the trade deadline.
content: Nearing the midpoint of the (newly extended) N.F.L. regular season, injuries are mounting and teams are sizing up their postseason chances as the Nov. 2 trade deadline looms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alan Cumming Would Like to Play the Title Character in ‘The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie’
description: “I would play her as a man, not in drag or anything.”
content: “I would play her as a man, not in drag or anything,” says the Tony-winning actor Alan Cumming, whose new memoir is “Baggage.” “Once you’ve played everything in ‘Macbeth’ (like I have) there are slim pickings in terms of great, complicated, messed-up Scots left to play!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: A New Era Takes Shape at the World’s Opera Capital
description: Serge Dorny and Vladimir Jurowski, the leaders of the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, are starting their tenure with Shostakovich’s unruly “The Nose.”
content: MUNICH — Serge Dorny quietly opened a door to the cavernous rehearsal hall of the Bavarian State Opera here one recent evening to see how Shostakovich’s “The Nose” was coming along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Journey to a Center of the Earth
description: Roman and Williams are opening a New York gallery devoted largely to ceramics (yes, they’re back).
content: The married founders of the architecture and design firm Roman and Williams, Robin Standefer and Stephen Alesch, are known for their dramatic room schemes that often use saturated colors and layers of objects to communicate richness and depth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Why China Is the World’s Last ‘Zero Covid’ Holdout
description: The government has staked its political legitimacy on controlling the virus better than other countries, especially its geopolitical rivals.
content: The trip began in Shanghai, where the couple, both former professors, joined a tour group of other retirees. They traveled through Gansu Province and Inner Mongolia, staying at a bed-and-breakfast and eating three times at the same lamb chop restaurant. Flying south to Xi’an, they dropped in to a 1,300-year-old temple. Their fellow tour group members checked out an art museum, strolled through parks and visited friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: China’s Hockey Team Is So Bad It Might Be Dropped From the Olympics
description: Months ahead of the Beijing Games, hockey officials are trying to balance competitive concerns with fears about embarrassing the host nation.
content: China has spent billions of dollars preparing for next year’s Winter Olympics. It has built entire ski resorts from scratch, constructed an array of new venues and even made plans to generate vast amounts of fake snow. But there is at least one shortcoming that all that spending has not been able to overcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Panorama of Design
description: A look at design-world events, products and people.
content: The Victorian-era retail entrepreneur William Whiteley long dreamed of building a London emporium to rival the Crystal Palace in its grandeur, a place where, as he purportedly put it, you could buy everything from a pin to an elephant. But in 1907, he was murdered by a man claiming to be his  son, and it was left to his acknowledged sons to realize his vision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa M. Collins
title: Eagles, Beavers, Sea Turtles: Why N.Y.C. Is Humming With Wildlife
description: New York is now ‘the greenest big city on earth,’ one naturalist said. Some creatures have noticed, and are staying for a while.
content: Adrian Benepe has spent much of his life promoting the outdoors in New York City, from serving as a park ranger in the 1970s to becoming the parks commissioner some 30 years later. Still, he is stunned at what he has seen around town lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Texas Nurse Sentenced to Death for Fatally Injecting 4 Heart Patients With Air
description: William Davis, who worked at Christus Mother Frances Hospital in Tyler, Texas, was convicted of capital murder on Oct. 19. His sentence will automatically be appealed.
content: A former Texas nurse was sentenced to death this week for injecting air into the arteries of four patients recovering from heart surgery, causing fatal brain damage, a court official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why Katie Couric Owned Up to Her Regrets
description: The former news anchor opens up about why she opened up.
content: Katie Couric has drawn fire for her new memoir, which chronicles over two decades of a TV news career that had her co-hosting with Matt Lauer (who became “cocky and reckless”), working under Les Moonves (“a close-talker with bad breath”) and in competition with the likes of Diane Sawyer (who was “everything I wasn’t”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Speer Goes to Hollywood’ Review: Expert Rebranding
description: A high-ranking Nazi leader attempts to whitewash his legacy in this disturbing, if single-note, documentary by Vanessa Lapa.
content: Albert Speer — one of Hitler’s closest advisers and his minister of Armaments and War Production — doesn’t actually go to Hollywood, but he does get bafflingly close. After serving 20 years in prison (he was the highest-ranking Nazi to avoid a death sentence at the Nuremberg Trials) Speer wrote “Inside the Third Reich,” a best-selling memoir that perked up the ears of the movie industry. In 1971, Paramount Pictures nearly took the bait and hired the screenwriter Andrew Birkin to hash out a script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Jonathan Weisman
title: Progressives withhold their support for the $1 trillion infrastructure bill, demanding more tangible progress.
description: Their opposition complicated plans for House leaders, who decided against holding a vote on the bill on Thursday despite President Biden’s entreaties earlier in the day.
content: President Biden’s urgent appeal for a fast House vote on the $1 trillion infrastructure bill on Thursday was quickly rejected by the House’s liberal wing, which continued to demand more tangible progress on its priority — the larger social policy and climate change bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Brett Favre Repays $600,000 in Mississippi Welfare Fraud Case
description: The Mississippi state auditor said that Mr. Favre, the Hall of Fame quarterback, could still be sued if he does not pay an additional $228,000 in interest that he owes.
content: Brett Favre, the Hall of Fame quarterback who was raised in Mississippi, this week paid the state back $600,000 that he owed after he improperly received welfare money as part of an extensive fraud scheme, according to the state auditor’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Chiasson and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: [If you want to make it to the moon]
description: From Dan Chiasson's “The Math Campers,” a book that is funky the way that math is.
content: Sometimes the moon looks so close you believe you’ll drive into it on a Friday night. Dan Chiasson is on one with “The Math Campers.” Existential and as real as that looming moon. The book demands to be read as a whole but is funky in the way that math is. If you remember your algebra, you know FOIL governs the order of binomial operations. And “If you want to make it to the moon” is the first of all questions, especially if you have no master and have been forced to name yourself in this world. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: We Knew Bolsonaro Was Guilty. Now We Have 1,288 Pages of Proof.
description: The Brazilian president’s catastrophic leadership has been painstakingly laid bare.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — If my country had managed just an average response to the pandemic, over 400,000 Brazilians would still be alive. That’s the stark conclusion of the epidemiologist Pedro Hallal, whose testimony, along with many others, is collected in the final report on the government’s handling of Covid-19. Released last week, it’s the culmination of a riveting monthslong congressional inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly
title: Saudi Finance Official Is Missing From Conference He Hosts
description: The unexplained absence of Yasir al-Rumayyan, who oversees the kingdom’s sovereign wealth fund, has highlighted concerns about a lack of transparency.
content: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — This week, as Saudi Arabia held its annual investment conference in Riyadh, a boisterous event that attracts business leaders and political officials from around the world, the big mystery was what happened to the host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: China sticks to a ‘zero-Covid’ strategy.
content: A recent outbreak of 240 coronavirus cases in China led to the lockdown of Lanzhou, a city of four million, as well as several smaller cities and parts of Beijing. Roughly 10,000 tourists are trapped in Ejin Banner, a region of Inner Mongolia, after the emergence of cases led to a lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karrie Jacobs
title: The Rise of the Designer Deli
description: Nothing says “New York” like a shabby shop that sells lox and bagels. But as the city’s delicatessens were threatened with extinction, a new species was unleashed.
content: Vicki Bodwell is an internet retail executive who moved to New York City from Texas in the late 1980s. Over breakfast recently, she told me in great detail about the very authentic bagel shop in TriBeCa where her family likes to go on Sunday mornings. As she spoke, I was thinking that there was a limit to how deep this shop’s roots could be. New York has many historically Jewish neighborhoods, but TriBeCa isn’t one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Motoko Rich
title: China plans to let vaccinated athletes skip quarantine at the Winter Olympics.
description: Competitors will still face strict rules at what is shaping up to be the most extraordinarily regulated, large-scale sporting event since the pandemic’s start and could be expelled for breaking them.
content: Athletes traveling to Beijing for the Winter Olympics will be able to skip quarantine if they are fully vaccinated, a signal that China is willing to ease some restrictions to ensure that teams make it to the Games in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: New data on breakthrough infections.
content: This summer, it seemed like everyone knew someone who had a breakthrough infection. Now, new federal data is giving us insights into how common these cases are, and who is most at risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s homes are a four-bedroom in Long Beach Township, N.J., and a three-bedroom in Port Chester, N.Y.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Implores Democrats to Support His Transformative Agenda
description: “The House and Senate majorities and my presidency will be determined by what happens in the next week,” President Biden told lawmakers on Thursday.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden was blunt. Democrats had to rally behind his $1.85 trillion economic and environmental spending bill, he told them on Thursday, because nothing less than his presidency was at stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Last Night in Soho’ Review: Dream Girls
description: Two young women from different eras form a psychic bond in Edgar Wright’s sumptuous and surprising horror movie.
content: Early in Edgar Wright’s “Last Night in Soho,” there’s a rapturous sequence showing Eloise (Thomasin McKenzie), a fashion student recently arrived in London, experiencing what seems to be a vivid dream. Entranced by a gorgeous young singer named Sandie (Anya Taylor-Joy, a vision in pink chiffon and blonde bouffant), Eloise finds her on a busy street where Sean Connery in “Thunderball” blazes from a gigantic marquee. As the two women enter a glamorous nightclub and Cilla Black’s aching 1964 hit, “You’re My World,” throbs on the soundtrack, they become mirror images and their stories irrevocably fuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman, Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Troy Closson
title: New York Braces for Worker Shortage as Vaccination Deadline Nears
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio predicted that serious disruptions would be avoided, even as thousands of police officers, firefighters and other essential workers remain unvaccinated.
content: City officials are bracing for the possibility that thousands of essential workers — including police officers, firefighters and sanitation employees — could be placed on unpaid leave starting Monday, when the city’s sweeping mandate requiring that almost all municipal workers receive at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine takes effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Do I Have Plans This Saturday? I’ve, Uh, Been Exposed.
description: Feeling overwhelmed at the prospect of socializing, some are going with a lie very few will argue with: Covid exposure.
content: Last winter Trysta Barwig was burned out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: The 37-Year-Olds Are Afraid of the 23-Year-Olds Who Work for Them
description: Twenty-somethings rolling their eyes at the habits of their elders is a longstanding trend, but many employers said there’s a new boldness in the way Gen Z dictates taste.
content: As a millennial with a habit of lurking on TikTok, Jessica Fain understood that skinny jeans and side parts were on the steady march toward extinction. But when Ms. Fain, who works as a product manager at a large tech company, heard that some of her favorite emojis might also be confronting retirement — namely that laughing-sobbing face — she decided to seek the counsel of her junior colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘My Hero Academia: World Heroes’ Mission’ Review: Boy on the Run
description: The third full-length movie in this franchise offers a formulaic plot and forgettable villain.
content: A villain aims to use a biological weapon to eliminate all mutants? Call Professor X: That story’s played now. Too bad it’s the narrative of “My Hero Academia: World Heroes’ Mission,” the missable third film based on the popular anime series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘Cicada’ Review: A New Relationship Buds as Old Wounds Reopen
description: Matthew Fifer writes and co-stars in this understated drama about a man struggling with his past as he forges a new bond.
content: The camera in “Cicada” dwells on scars, literal and metaphorical. There’s a rough, discolored line running down the stomach of Sam (Sheldon D. Brown), the new boyfriend of Ben (Matthew Fifer). Ben drags his finger along that line while the two are in bed together. And there are the ambiguous nightmares that take Ben back to his Long Island childhood home and the beach nearby, the noise of cicadas and waves of the nearby ocean deafening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Wes Anderson’s Dream of France, and the Paris I Remember
description: With “The French Dispatch,” the director’s latest, yet another American artist falls under the country’s spell. The Times’s Paris bureau chief recalls when the same thing happened to him.
content: PARIS — At the premiere on Sunday before the release of his latest movie, “The French Dispatch,” Wes Anderson stood onstage in a rumpled, brownish suit and told the crowd packed into a Champs-Élysées theater, “I have a French air about me.” He had, he said, “spent my whole life feeling I am in a French movie.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: Smalls is the New York jazz equivalent of a sparring gym or, looked at another way, an Off Broadway theater. It’s the proving ground where rising improvisers size each other up and take their cuts; at the same time, they’re testing their formula on a receptive and relatively young audience. Of course, part of what makes this little basement so fertile is the presence of elders, too, and many of the brightest moments on its stage come thanks to conversations between the generations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Families of Charleston Massacre Victims Reach $88 Million Settlement
description: The settlement with the Justice Department includes millions for the families and survivors of the shooting at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in 2015.
content: The Justice Department reached an $88 million settlement with the families of nine Black parishioners who were killed by a white supremacist in a South Carolina church in 2015, and with survivors of the shooting, the authorities and lawyers said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: How Biden’s $2 Trillion in Tax Increases Target Companies and the Rich
description: The proposal to fund the president’s sprawling spending plan mostly turns up the dial on more conventional tax policies, while trying to curb maneuvers that allow tax avoidance.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s new plan to pay for his climate change and social policy package includes nearly $2 trillion in tax increases on corporations and the rich. But many of the more contentious and untested proposals that Democrats have been considering in recent weeks were left on the cutting-room floor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Dumbo, Hell’s Kitchen and Glendale.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Driven to Distraction by Thwup-Thwup-Thwup
description: The pandemic quieted the soundtrack of the city. Now complaints about noise from helicopters are surging.
content: It’s Thursday. We’ll look at something some New Yorkers hear too often — noise from helicopters. We’ll also celebrate the dedication of the Statue of Liberty 135 years ago today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Helene Cooper
title: France and the United States Seek an Elusive Reconciliation
description: The Biden administration is poised to offer the French some defense-related emollients after their falling out over a sabotaged submarine deal. But some damage may last.
content: PARIS — Since their relationship imploded in a welter of recrimination six weeks ago, poisoned by what France saw as a betrayal by the United States over a sabotaged submarine deal, the two countries have worked hard to overcome the dispute. France has demanded “concrete” results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Hurries to Burn More Coal, Putting Climate Goals at Risk
description: Faced with electricity shortages, the country is racing to expand mining despite risks to the environment, miner safety and the economy.
content: LINFEN, China — Desperate to meet its electricity needs, China is opening up new coal production exceeding what all of Western Europe mines in a year, at a tremendous cost to the global effort to fight climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Climate Change Became the Largest Part of Biden Spending Bill
description: As paid family leave and other priorities were taken out of the president’s plan, the largest piece became a $555 billion plan to fight climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — Climate has emerged as the single largest category in President Biden’s new framework for a huge spending bill, placing global warming at the center of his party’s domestic agenda in a way that was hard to imagine just a few years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Joy Ride’ Review: Still Standing
description: Bobcat Goldthwait and Dana Gould share the stand-up stage in “Joy Ride,” trading war stories, family nightmares and twisted anecdotes.
content: You can think of “Joy Ride” as similar to “The Trip” but with stand-up comedy where the food would be. The recipe is part meat-and-potatoes joke-telling — the comics Bobcat Goldthwait and Dana Gould doing joint sets at clubs — and part driving around trading war stories and family nightmares.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Roh’ Review: I See Dead People
description: This atmospheric and grisly horror movie from Malaysia sees a single mother and her children rattled by the arrival of mysterious strangers.
content: When a ghoulish little girl caked in mud suddenly appears near the isolated hut of a single mother, Mak (Farah Ahmad), and her two children living in the Malaysian jungle, things take a turn for the sinister. Not that the family — impoverished and in denial of their father’s death — was doing particularly well before the arrival of the lost child, who rattles them with a morbid prophecy then slashes her own throat within the first fifteen minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter and Siobhan Burke
title: Kandis Williams Envisions Dancing Bodies Without Borders
description: The artist’s “A Line,” her first New York solo show, sets the tone for the ambitious new 52 Walker, run by the gallerist Ebony L. Haynes.
content: Dance is both the central theme and a lens to inspect contemporary culture in “A Line,” the debut New York solo exhibition of the multimedia artist Kandis Williams, and the inaugural presentation of 52 Walker, the new space that the David Zwirner gallery has opened in Tribeca.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Heilbrunn
title: The Inexorable Rise of Angela Merkel
description: Kati Marton’s “The Chancellor” describes how a smart and talented woman overcame numerous obstacles on her way to becoming the leader of Germany.
content: THE CHANCELLOR
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Former School Safety Officer Is Charged in the Fatal Shooting of a Teenager
description: The former officer, Eddie Gonzalez, was charged with one count of murder after he shot Manuela Rodriguez, 18, near a high school in Long Beach, Calif., last month.
content: A former California school safety officer who fatally shot an unarmed 18-year-old girl last month has been charged with murder, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Antlers’ Review: Buck Wild
description: An environmental parable is tucked inside this gloomy film about a creature that terrorizes a small Oregon town.
content: “Antlers,” a moody muddle by Scott Cooper (“Hostiles”), attempts to do for the wendigo, a man-eating, steroidal, elk-like creature from Algonquin folklore, what “Jaws” did for the great white shark: pare a beast to its protuberances and set it loose on an economically-anxious hamlet where basic human well-being is a luxury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand will cut the amount of quarantine time for travelers in half.
description: New Zealand’s government announced on Thursday that it would halve the mandatory quarantine period for travelers to the country next month.
content: New Zealand’s government announced on Thursday that it would halve the mandatory quarantine period for travelers to the country next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Treffinger
title: How Low Can You Go (Sofa-wise)?
description: Advice for decorating, cleaning and warming your home.
content: What is the ideal sofa height? I’m pretty tall, but my partner is about six inches shorter than me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Eleonore Von Trapp Campbell, of the ‘Sound of Music’ Family, Dies at 90
description: She was a member of the Trapp Family Singers, which toured internationally, though she herself was not depicted in the musical or the film.
content: Eleonore von Trapp Campbell, the second daughter of Maria von Trapp, whose Austrian family was depicted in the stage musical and the beloved movie “The Sound of Music,” died on Sunday in Northfield, Vt. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Patients Must Be Warned of Breast Implant Risks, F.D.A. Says
description: A decade after scientists identified a link between certain implants and cancer, the agency ordered “black box” warnings and a new checklist of risks for patients to review.
content: Federal regulators on Wednesday placed so-called black box warnings on breast implant packaging and told manufacturers to sell the devices only to health providers who review the potential risks with patients before surgery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: More access to a Covid-19 antiviral pill.
content: The American pharmaceutical giant Merck granted a royalty-free license for its promising Covid-19 antiviral pill to a U.N.-backed nonprofit organization. The agreement restricts sales to developing countries and excludes most middle-income countries — including China and Russia, as well as many Latin American nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘See How the Dixie Fire Created Its Own Weather’
description: In this lesson, students will explore a 3-D model created by The New York Times to show how the largest blaze of the year generated storm clouds that powered its own weather systems.
content: Featured Article: “See How the Dixie Fire Created Its Own Weather” by Nadja Popovich, Noah Pisner, Nicholas Bartzokas, Evan Grothjan, Daniel Mangosing, Karthik Patanjali and Scott Reinhard
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Two Theaters, Different Worlds
description: Munich is throwing off a provincial reputation to become a global cultural powerhouse. Yet tensions between local and cosmopolitan impulses in the city’s playhouses remain.
content: MUNICH — This month, hundreds of elegant Bavarians, many decked out in the region’s traditional dress of lederhosen and dirndls, gathered for the festive opening of the new Volkstheater, a striking and luxurious performing arts complex built into the cobbled courtyards of a 19th-century abattoir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: What to Know About the Trial of Kyle Rittenhouse
description: Mr. Rittenhouse will stand trial for the shootings of three men — two of whom died — in the aftermath of demonstrations in Kenosha, Wis.
content: Kyle Rittenhouse, an 18-year-old from Antioch, Ill., will stand trial on Nov. 1 for the shootings of three men — two of whom died — in the aftermath of demonstrations in Kenosha, Wis., in August 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: China’s New Climate Pledge Changes Little, in Bad Omen for Global Talks
description: China’s updated targets for cutting emissions to fight climate change reiterate what its leader pledged nearly a year ago. That doesn’t bode well for progress at next week’s global climate summit.
content: China formalized the pledges its leader announced last year, but the country went no further, in an official update of its targets to fight climate change, which were submitted on Thursday with the United Nations climate change agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Brother Should Get a Prenup, Right?
description: An older sister wonders how to talk to her sibling about premarital agreements.
content: My younger brother told me that he is proposing to his girlfriend of six years. He’s 25 — which, from my perspective as his older sister in a committed, unmarried relationship, is too young to propose. On top of this, his soon-to-be fiancée has extreme social anxiety, which has kept our family from getting to know her well. I am supportive of their relationship because my brother is deeply in love. Still, I know that if I were to get married, I would make sure my partner and I signed a prenuptial agreement. How can I broach the subject with my brother? He’s the first of his friends to marry, and he might not know how common such agreements are or how much one might protect him down the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The 10 Best Books of 2021: A Virtual Event Announcing Our List
description: On Nov. 30, Times subscribers will be the first to find out what made this year’s 10 Best Books list from editors at the Book Review.
content: How do editors of The New York Times Book Review choose the annual 10 Best Books list? Which fiction and nonfiction works will make the cut this year, and why?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Republicans Assail Garland Over Justice Department Schools Memo
description: Republicans said the Biden administration was seeking to intimidate parents concerned about school policies. The attorney general cited a spike in threats.
content: Republicans berated Attorney General Merrick B. Garland on Wednesday over the Justice Department’s initiative to address threats of violence and harassment directed at school administrators, teachers and school board members, incidents that have increased as education has become a culture war battleground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: 16 New Books Coming in November
description: Memoirs from Ai Weiwei, Huma Abedin and Will Smith; new fiction from Gary Shteyngart and Neal Stephenson; and plenty more.
content: In this story of family, politics, art and exile, the author traces the life of his father, who was a prominent poet in China, alongside his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Only the Animals’ Review: A Missing Woman, a Cruel World
description: When an outsider disappears from a remote region in France, she leaves a mystery and a lot of messy complications in her wake.
content: What would movies do without troublesome women — the cruel, the cold, the difficult, the dispensable? That’s one of the takeaways of “Only the Animals,” a cynical French puzzler from the director Dominik Moll about a woman who goes missing. Her disappearance stirs up the usual interest; that she’s white and wealthy helps. There’s a police investigation and news reports and plenty of pain and suffering, but the many tears the movie vigorously pumps aren’t necessarily spilled over her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Lisa Friedman
title: Oil Executives Grilled Over Industry’s Role in Climate Disinformation
description: In a historic hearing, the leaders of some of the most powerful energy companies in the world appeared before a House panel to face questioning on climate change.
content: At a heated hearing on Thursday, Democrats had some big questions for the chief executives of Exxon Mobil, Chevron, BP and Shell: Would they pledge to stop lobbying against efforts to reduce emissions? And were they willing to tell their powerful trade groups to stop working against electric vehicles?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘A Mouthful of Air’ Review: Depression Clouds a Domestic Idyll
description: Amanda Seyfried stars as a young mother suffering from postpartum depression in Amy Koppelman’s weepy adaptation of her novel.
content: A young mother battles postpartum depression in the arid melodrama “A Mouthful of Air.” Living in Manhattan in the ’90s, Julie (Amanda Seyfried) is a vision of bliss. Sunlight pours through the windows of her vibrantly colored apartment as she lays sprawled beside her cherubic infant son. But minutes later, the domestic idyll cracks when Julie settles on the floor to slit her wrists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Souvenir Part II’ Review: Life, as She Imagines It
description: In the sequel to her art-house favorite “The Souvenir,” Joanna Hogg picks up the story of a young woman’s journey to becoming an artist.
content: Deep into “The Souvenir Part II,” a young woman walks through a hall of mirrors as if in a dream. It is a freighted moment for the character, a film student whose lover died not long ago. After struggling with her grief and her art, she seems on the cusp of a creative breakthrough: She’s made her graduate movie and her mother, father and friends are there to see it. As she walks among her mirrored reflections, she also seems to be passing her many different selves — the dutiful daughter, the drifting student, the bereft survivor — now all in service to her role as an artist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Sean Penn the Focus of N.L.R.B. Amid Comments on Hours and Food at Vaccine Site
description: Two online commenters complained of working 18-hour days and not getting food from Krispy Kreme or Subway. Penn saw “narcissism” and “betrayal.”
content: A nonprofit group co-founded by Sean Penn is facing a National Labor Relations Board hearing over an accusation that he implicitly threatened employees after complaints about long hours and the food served during a Covid-19 vaccination effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Val Bisoglio, Oft-Cast Character Actor, Dies at 95
description: He was seen on “Quincy, M.E.” and “The Sopranos.” He also memorably played John Travolta’s father in “Saturday Night Fever.”
content: By 1986, after 30 years in the business, Val Bisoglio had made such an impression as a character actor that Danny Arnold, a producer casting a new police series called “Joe Bash,” wrote in a casting notice for a particular part simply that he was looking for “a Val Bisoglio-type.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Thålin
title: Vaccine Policy Should Consider the Power of ‘Hybrid Immunity’
description: Should some people — like kids — who have had Covid-19 get one vaccine dose?
content: As a physician in a Covid-19 care unit, I celebrate the vaccines as one of medicine’s greatest triumphs. They provide extraordinary protection against severe disease and death, and are the world’s best option for returning to a more normal life. As a scientist and lead investigator for a study on Covid-19 immunity, I have also come to appreciate the significance of so-called natural immunity acquired by those who have had Covid-19, and the power of “hybrid immunity” — the protection gained when such people also get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Violet’ Review: In Two Minds
description: Olivia Munn battles a bullying voice in her head in this unusual psychological drama.
content: Olivia Munn gives a terrific performance as the title character in “Violet,” if only her director, Justine Bateman, would allow us to see it. Crowding the screen with jarring sounds and disturbing visuals, Bateman experiments with so many cinematic frills and fancies that Munn’s touching work is too often obscured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Is the Billionaire Tax Legal?
description: Democrats are weighing their options for taxing the ultrawealthy.
content: No one is better equipped to mount a constitutional challenge to a proposed tax on the unrealized capital gains of the ultrawealthy than, well, the 700 or so billionaires who may face the tax. And rumblings that the Democratic proposal may not survive Supreme Court review — to say nothing of the opposition from Senator Joe Manchin, Democrat of West Virginia, whose vote is crucial for the tax to pass — appear to have inspired a new idea to raise revenue from the rich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: Design Books That Mine the Exotic
description: Five new titles burrow into design’s past to reveal a universe that is ‘both perfumed and colorful.’
content: Excavating deeply into design history, and the ways the past is continuously reinterpreted, can suggest paths to fresh ideas. These five new books reveal how much monastery desks, rosebushes tangled in ancient orchards and Art Deco dreamscapes have to offer the modern imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Atlanta Heads Home, Hoping to Find Strength in Defiance
description: A region’s fans have their share of enemies, real or imagined, and the atmosphere at their World Series games should be electric.
content: HOUSTON — The Atlanta Braves have not won a home game in the World Series since the night they clinched a championship in 1995. That was three stadiums ago, before Turner Field (a repurposed Olympics venue) and their more recent move to Cobb County.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Classical Albums to Hear Right Now
description: A rising singer, a jazz-choral amalgam, a quartet meditation and standards by Brahms and Chopin are among the highlights of recent recordings.
content: Last month, the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra announced that its music director, Manfred Honeck, would extend his contract through the 2027-28 season. Good for them. As I wrote two years ago, these forces have been setting new standards in the standards, their records combining astonishing playing with conducting that is full of ideas — sometimes, perhaps, a little too full.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Jumaane Williams Runs for One Office With an Eye on Another
description: Mr. Williams is exploring a run for governor even as he is poised to win his first full term as public advocate after five elections.
content: When New Yorkers show up to vote on Nov. 2, they will see a familiar name listed on the ballot for public advocate: Jumaane D. Williams, the Democratic incumbent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: This Is Only a Test
description: Mmmm … brains …
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’m not certain what, if anything, the puzzle editors have up their sleeves for Halloween, but perhaps we are seeing a sample of it today, as the spooky celebration falls on Sunday in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: A Farewell to Readers, With Hope
description: A columnist offers lessons learned from decades on the front lines of reporting and explains why he is leaving to run for office.
content: My life was transformed when I was 25 years old and nervously walked into a job interview in the grand office of Abe Rosenthal, the legendary and tempestuous executive editor of The New York Times. At one point, I disagreed with him, so I waited for him to explode and call security. Instead, he stuck out his hand and offered me a job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abrahm Lustgarten
title: When the World Is on the Brink, $3.5 Trillion Is a Pittance
description: What we don’t spend now to deal with climate change will cost us much more later.

content: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. — As a series of videos depicting a violent rally in Charlottesville, Va., were played in court on Thursday, Elizabeth Sines reached for a tissue to wipe away her tears. title: What Do Authors Want Us to Know About Themselves? It Depends.

content: TELL IT LIKE IT IS What can we learn about authors from the brief biographies on the back of their book or on their website? Many of these descriptions are the literary equivalent of announcements on the subway: omnipresent but saying nothing. Why don’t authors seize the opportunity to tell us about their pets or unusual hobbies? (Or at least get real about where they live — and I say this as someone who lives in suburban New Jersey, not “outside New York City.”) So what a pleasure it was to stumble across this refreshing take on Lauren Blackwood, whose debut novel, “Within These Wicked Walls,” makes an entrance at No. 5 on the young adult hardcover list: “When not writing, she’s a physical therapy assistant who doesn’t really know how to settle on one career field.” Welcome to the club, Ms. Blackwood. “Within These Wicked Walls” is a fantasy retelling of “Jane Eyre” starring an exorcist named Andromeda and a handsome young heir named Magnus Rochester. As one exuberant Goodreads reviewer put it, “If you love kissing, creepy stuff and banter for days, PULL UP A CHAIR YOU’RE IN THE RIGHT PLACE.”

content: For a true TV devotee, watching the latest episode is just the beginning. Depending on the show at hand, there are plot twists and character revelations to dissect, theories to discuss and historical context to plumb.
